We generate our dataset following the procedure ofÂ [5].
We render 64Ã—64646464\!\times\!64 images with BlenderÂ [13].
Each image contains one of three objects (sphere, cube, or cylinder) in one of eight colors (red, purple, yellow, blue, green, cyan, gray, or brown).
For each object/color combination, we generate 2000 samples, randomizing the object size, material (rubber or metallic), position, and lightning.
We assign disjoint subsets of object/color combinations to the pretraining, fine-tuning, and evaluation sets, as summarized in TableÂ 1.
The validation set contains a mix of in-domain (ID) and out-of-distribution (OOD) data, while the test set if fully OOD. The validation set serves to select hyperparameters and perform early stopping.

references:
We report our main results in TableÂ 2.
We compare models built with an EBMâ€“ or CLâ€“pretrained vision encoder, with a baseline that is not pretrained, i.e. only trained with supervision on the VQA data.
The baseline overfits to the particular object/color combinations of the VQA data and is therefore unable to generalize to the novel combinations of the validation (ID+OOD data) nor test splits (fully OOD data).
Of our pretrained models, the CL method (SimCLRâ‹†â‹†\star) achieves the highest, near-perfect accuracy of 99.26% on the test set.
It seems to better disentangle the representations of shape from color, such that the VQA model can generalize to new combinations at test time without overfitting to the particular combinations seen during training.
EBM pretraining also improves generalization (86.74% on the test set) but with a high variance across runs (standard deviation of 8.34%).
SimCLRâ‹†â‹†\star shows no such stability issues (standard deviation of 0.29%).

references:
On five out of our seven datasets, EBMs are superior to CL (see TableÂ 3).
They can distinguish ID from OOD data almost perfectly (AUROC of âˆ¼similar-to\sim1.0).
However, when the OOD data is visually similar to the training data (e.g. images of backgrounds and cones), the detection performance of our EBM falls well below CL.
The estimated energies appear generally reliable for filtering out OOD samples, but they seem less able to spot fine-grained differences.
See also FigureÂ 7 for the distributions of scores over different datasets.

The baseline model (TableÂ 4, second row) unsurprisingly overfits the object/color combinations of the training data and is therefore unable to generalize to novel combinations at test time.
The model obtains an accuracy of 100%percent100100\% on questions about spheres (same combinations in training and test) but 0%percent00\% on cubes and cylinders (OOD combinations).
The calibration is also poor (high ECE of 71.5471.5471.54%) indicating that the model is confident about its wrong predictions.

(TableÂ 4, third row) shows poor accuracy and calibration similar to the baseline.
Careful inspection revealed that the classification objective quickly dominates the energy learning.
In other words, the model could not simultaneously predict correct answers and be capable of generating new images.
The classification loss would typically converge much faster and, to minimize the energy loss, the model would start generating non-realistic images that always give a high energy.
The energy learning objective is thus ineffective in this regime.
We mitigate the dominance of the classification objective by down-scaling the corresponding term by a constant factor (0.1 proved effective).
The resulting model then learns to produce naturally-looking images (see FigureÂ 8, bottom row).
Nevertheless, at some point during training, we always observed that the model would start generating noisy images that quickly diverge from the training data (see FigureÂ 8, top row).
We solve this issue with early stopping, which we trigger when the energies of real and generated images diverge past a threshold: |Eğœ½â€‹(ğ’™â€²)âˆ’Eğœ½â€‹(ğ’™)|>0.8subscriptğ¸ğœ½superscriptğ’™â€²subscriptğ¸ğœ½ğ’™0.8|E_{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}({\boldsymbol{x}}^{\prime})-E_{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}({\boldsymbol{x}})|>0.8.

(TableÂ 4, fourth row) gives a higher overall accuracy (49.10%percent49.1049.10\%) as well as a better calibration (ECE of 36.5536.5536.55%).
Contrary to the baseline, this model can therefore correctly handle some of the OOD data, although it still often confuses cubes and cylinders with relatively high confidence.
